Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: The Materials Computation Center Outreach Effort
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Materials Computation Center at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign continues its international outreach efforts. These include an international travel program that sends young scientists to workshops, summer schools and conferences in Europe, and specifically to events organized by the European networks CECAM and Psi-k that are concerned with topics in molecular and electronic simulation over a wide range of applications. Such networks conduct many workshops in scientific disciplines imminently relevant to materials research such as molecular and electronic simulation, condensed matter physics, materials chemistry, polymers, nanostructures, and electronic materials. The number of participating institutions and the number of workshops are both growing. The topics of the workshops evolve yearly to cover key, contemporary areas of computational materials science.

The workshops present valuable opportunities for exposure to and specialized training in new scientific trends. Sending young, US-based scientists to these international workshops enhances scientific partnerships in an immediate, productive way. While the US is strong in innovative techniques and high-performance computing, the European strength lies in applications of existing methodology; a larger number of researchers there develop computer codes and perform materials simulations. Synergy adds value to both research communities. In addition, the MCC proposes continuation of support of the annual US "New Methods in Electronic Structure" workshop by funding the travel of 15-20 participating junior scientists and by hosting the website and presentation materials at the University of Illinois.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the “Materials Computation Center Outreach Effort: Travel Program” is to support U.S. capabilities, activities, and partnerships researching simulations of atoms and molecules, in all kinds of materials and environmental conditions. To that aim, the Travel Program offers funds to U.S. students and junior scientists participating in international workshops held in Europe and participating in an annual American workshop focused on recent developments in electronic structure. 

In total, the program has funded 156 trips for young scientists from 136 different U.S. institutions, to participate in 83 workshops.

Sending young, U.S.-based scientists to these international workshops enhances scientific partnerships immediately. Specific benefits awardees have described are:

  • hearing feedback on their research from experts they may otherwise not meet
  • helping to build resources for the community, such as software code libraries
  • learning new methods in hands-on sessions, to share with their research groups at home
  • cross-pollinating ideas among related disciplines and approaches, such as computation vs. experiments
  • speaking opportunities and potential job placements which build careers
  • receiving encouragement to pursue this work
  • enhanced impact abroad of research activities based in the US 

Combining U.S. and European strengths: The Travel Program has partnered with two European/UK research groups, CECAM and Psi-K, who hold workshops and schools on topics in materials research, such as molecular and electronic simulation, condensed matter physics, materials chemistry, polymers, nanostructures, and electronic materials. While the US is strong in innovative techniques and high-performance computing, the European strength lies in applications of existing methodology; a larger number of researchers there develop computer codes and perform materials simulations. For attendees, the international aspect is vital. For example, a graduate student at the University of California at Irvine, attended "Psi-k Conference on ab initio Calculations of Processes in Materials," in San Sebastian, Spain, September 2015, and met European collaborators for the first time, "... I have been working with them for almost two years and yet this was our first in-person meeting. That moment of human connection truly reminded me as to why we go through the effort and expense of conferences, particularly international ones. I have a strong interest in science policy, and a growing subset of that world is science diplomacy...I was able to practice this skill set by interacting with physicists from all across the world..."

Many fields of study: The topics of the workshops cover many applications of computation from geophysics to cancer. For example, a graduate student at Sloan Kettering Institute attended "Molecular and chemical kinetics," held in Berlin, Germany, September 2015. She wrote, "This workshop featured high-caliber presentations far beyond those of a typical conference...I was exposed to many researchers in tangential fields who used systems and models that can be applied to my own work, including equations representing a mutational resistance model in HIV which could be extended to my interest in mutations in cancer." 

Funding demographics: Because smaller institutions are less likely to offer specialized courses on newer research topics, the Travel Program gives priority to students and junior researchers at smaller colleges/universities. Other funding priorities are female, Black, and Hispanic/Latin researchers. For example in funded applications, 25% were female applicants and 11% self-reported as Hispanic or Latino/a—which is higher than the "all-time high" of 20% women and 3% Hispanic/Latino & Latina published in a 2014 report by the American Institute for Physics about PhD demographics. The positions of the awards are 2% Undergraduates, 62% Graduate Students, 26% Postdoctoral researchers, 2% Research Scientists, and 8% are Assistant or Associate Professors.

Additional activity: The Travel Award program also provides $8k to support travel and housing for US students and junior researchers to attend the annual Workshop on Recent Developments in Electronic Structure, averaging 80-120 participants.

Photos by Carlos H. Borca, who attended the 7th Time-Dependent Density-Functional Theory: Prospects and Applications, September 2016.
